Package com.github.yellowstonegames.place

Class GrowingTreeMazeGenerator

java.lang.Object
com.github.yellowstonegames.place.GrowingTreeMazeGenerator
All Implemented Interfaces:
PlaceGenerator
public class GrowingTreeMazeGenerator extends Object implements PlaceGenerator
A maze generator that can be configured using an IntUnaryOperator, which can be customized for the app. Based in part on code from Jamis Buck's blog. This defaults to newest for its IntUnaryOperator, but random is also good to try; you can specify a IntUnaryOperator with generate(IntUnaryOperator).
Here, an IntUnaryOperator used to choose cells takes a size (exclusive upper bound) and returns some int between 0 (inclusive) and that size (exclusive). These are typically lambdas.

    newest
    Produces high-quality mazes that are very similar to those produced by a recursive back-tracking algorithm.
    final IntUnaryOperator
    oldest
    Produces mostly straight corridors that dead-end at the map's edge; probably only useful with mix(IntUnaryOperator, double, IntUnaryOperator, double).
    final IntUnaryOperator
    random
    Produces chaotic, jumbled spans of corridors, often with dead-ends, that are similar to those produced by Prim's algorithm.

    • newest

      public final IntUnaryOperator newest
      Produces high-quality mazes that are very similar to those produced by a recursive back-tracking algorithm.
      Example: 
       ┌─────┬───────┬───┬─────────┬─────┬───┐

    • oldest

      public final IntUnaryOperator oldest
      Produces mostly straight corridors that dead-end at the map's edge; probably only useful with mix(IntUnaryOperator, double, IntUnaryOperator, double).
      Example: 
       ┌─┬─┬─┬─┬─┬─┬─┬───────────────────────┐

    • random

      public final IntUnaryOperator random
      Produces chaotic, jumbled spans of corridors, often with dead-ends, that are similar to those produced by Prim's algorithm. This works well when mixed with newest using mix(IntUnaryOperator, double, IntUnaryOperator, double), and not as well when mixed with oldest.
      Example: 
       ┌─────────────┬───────────┬───────────┐
 │.............│...........│...........│
 ├─┬─┬─┬────.┌─┘.┌─┐.──┐.──┤.──┐.──┐.│.│
 │.│.│.│.....│...│.│...│...│...│...│.│.│
 │.│.│.└─┬──.│.┌─┘.└─┐.└─┬─┘.──┴───┤.│.│
 │.│.│...│...│.│.....│...│.........│.│.│
 │.│.└─┐.└─┐.│.│.┌─┬─┤.┌─┤.──┐.────┴─┼─┤
 │.....│...│.....│.│.│.│.│...│.......│.│
 ├────.├──.└──.──┘.│.└─┘.│.──┴─┐.│.──┘.│
 │.....│...........│...........│.│.....│
 ├────.└──.│.│.│.──┘.──────────┴─┴─┐.──┤
 │.........│.│.│...................│...│
 ├──────.│.│.│.│.────────────────┐.└─┬─┤
 │.......│.│.│.│.................│...│.│
 ├────.│.│.│.│.├─┬─┐.│.│.│.──┐.──┴───┘.│

  • Method Details

    • getPlaceGrid

      public char[][] getPlaceGrid()
      Gets the most recently-produced maze as a 2D char array, usually produced by calling generate() or generate(IntUnaryOperator). This passes a direct reference and not a copy, so you can normally modify the returned array to propagate changes back into this PlaceGenerator.
      Specified by:
      getPlaceGrid in interface PlaceGenerator
      Returns:
      the most recently-produced dungeon/map as a 2D char array

    • getEnvironment

      public int[][] getEnvironment()
      Description copied from interface: PlaceGenerator
      Gets the most recently-produced place's environment as a 2D int array, where each int is typically a constant in DungeonTools like DungeonTools.NATURAL_WALL or DungeonTools.ROOM_FLOOR.
      Specified by:
      getEnvironment in interface PlaceGenerator
      Returns:
      the environment of the most recently-produced place, as a 2D int array

    • generate

      public char[][] generate()
      Builds and returns a 2D char array maze by using newest with generate(IntUnaryOperator).
      Specified by:
      generate in interface PlaceGenerator
      Returns:
      dungeon, after filling it with a maze

    • generate

      public char[][] generate(IntUnaryOperator choosing)
      Builds and returns a 2D char array maze using the provided chooser method object. The most maze-like dungeons use newest, the least maze-like use oldest, and the most jumbled use random or a mix of others using mix(IntUnaryOperator, double, IntUnaryOperator, double).
      Parameters:
      choosing - the callback object for making the split decision
      Returns:
      dungeon, after filling it with a maze

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object

    • mix

      public IntUnaryOperator mix(IntUnaryOperator methodA, double chanceA, IntUnaryOperator methodB, double chanceB)
      Mixes two IntUnaryOperator values, like newest and random, given a weight for each, and produces a new IntUnaryOperator that randomly (respecting weight) picks one of those IntUnaryOperators each time it is used.
      Parameters:
      methodA - the first IntUnaryOperator to mix; must not be null
      chanceA - the weight to favor choosing methodA
      methodB - the second IntUnaryOperator to mix; must not be null
      chanceB - the weight to favor choosing methodB
      Returns:
      a IntUnaryOperator that randomly picks between methodA and methodB each time it is used
